message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest hyper-IgE syndrome or Job syndrome, which is characterized by an eczematous rash, recurrent soft tissue infections, and high levels of IgE. The deficiency of T helper 17 cells is consistent with this diagnosis. The increased susceptibility to infection is most likely due to impaired chemotaxis of neutrophils, as Job syndrome is associated with impaired neutrophil function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's recurrent infections suggest an immunodeficiency disorder. The deficiency of T helper 17 cells indicates a possible diagnosis of hyper-IgE syndrome. This syndrome is characterized by impaired function of neutrophils, leading to recurrent abscesses and infections. Thus, the most likely cause of the patient’s increased susceptibility to infection is impaired chemotaxis of neutrophils, which is a characteristic feature of hyper-IgE syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation along with the deficiency of T helper 17 cells suggests Hyper IgE syndrome. Patients with this syndrome have impaired chemotaxis of neutrophils, which leads to their increased susceptibility to infection. Impaired actin assembly in lymphocytes is seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. Impaired Ig class-switching in lymphocytes is seen in common variable immunodeficiency. Impaired interferon-γ secretion by Th1 cells is seen in Chronic granulomatous disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s susceptibility to infections and the presence of eczematous rash suggest the diagnosis of Job syndrome (hyper IgE syndrome). The immunodeficiency in Job syndrome results in impaired chemotaxis of neutrophils, leading to recurrent bacterial and fungal infections. The other options are not associated with this syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s susceptibility to infections, specifically soft tissue abscesses and pneumonia, suggests impaired chemotaxis of neutrophils, which are responsible for fighting infections. The other options listed do not fit with the patient’s symptoms and lab findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and physical examination findings suggest Job syndrome, also known as hyper-IgE syndrome. This syndrome is caused by a deficiency in the signaling pathway of chemokine receptors, leading to impaired chemotaxis of neutrophils and increased susceptibility to bacterial and fungal infections. Option (B) refers to Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, which is characterized by impaired actin assembly in lymphocytes. Option (C) refers to a class-switching defect, which is seen in patients with X-linked hyper-IgM syndrome. Option (D) refers to a defect in Th1 cell function, which can result in increased susceptibility to intracellular pathogens.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of recurrent abscesses and pneumonia suggests impaired chemotaxis of neutrophils, which are important in fighting bacterial infections. The deficiency of T helper 17 cells may contribute to the eczematous rash and white plaques, but does not explain the increased susceptibility to infections. Impaired actin assembly in lymphocytes can cause Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, which presents with eczema, thrombocytopenia, and increased susceptibility to infections, but the patient does not have a history of thrombocytopenia. Impaired Ig class-switching in lymphocytes can cause hyper-IgM syndrome, which can also present with recurrent infections, but the patient’s IgE level is elevated, not low. Impaired interferon-γ secretion by Th1 cells can cause chronic granulomatous disease, which presents with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, but the patient’s leukocyte count and eosinophilia are not consistent with this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of recurrent infections suggests an immunodeficiency. The deficiency of T helper 17 cells suggests a susceptibility to Candida albicans infections. Among the options, impaired chemotaxis of neutrophils is the most likely cause of the patient’s increased susceptibility to infection, as it can result in the inability of neutrophils to migrate to sites of infection and effectively fight infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a genetic disorder called Hyper-IgE syndrome, which causes recurrent infections and a characteristic rash. Neutrophils are important in fighting infections, and impaired chemotaxis of neutrophils would explain the increased susceptibility to infections in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and symptoms suggest possible Hyper-IgE syndrome. Among the options, only impaired chemotaxis of neutrophils is consistent with the recurrent infections seen in this syndrome. Impaired actin assembly in lymphocytes is related to Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. Impaired Ig class-switching in lymphocytes is related to immunoglobulin deficiencies, and impaired interferon-γ secretion by Th1 cells is related to chronic granulomatous disease.
